body.p: One useful tool for understanding how DITA modules can be combined into multiple authoring "shells" is Jarno Elovirta's web-based DITA Generator application.
Basically, Jarno has provided a buffet-style form into which you specify three pieces of information and it generates a ready-to-use authoring "shell" for what you want.

ol.li: Specify a base information (topic/map) type. This serves as the "parent" DTD to be modified (specialized).
A set of domain vocabularty modules that you would like to include in your new authoring "shell."
Some information about naming your new authoring "shell."

body.p: DITA Generator collects all this information and generates a ready-to-use authoring "shell" (DTD) that contains only what you have specified to be included.
The DITA Generator tool exposes the way that all DITA specializations are constructed from underlying domain vocabulary, structural, and constraint modules.
